awd_titl_txt: Analysis and design of decentralized control systems in the presence of uncertain latency or system parameters
awd_abstract_narration:
This research addresses the analysis and design of decentralized feedback control systems. Such systems include: the power grid, wireless networks, and medical tele-robotics. In these applications, distributed information-gathering is taking place but decision-making is often made locally using small subsets of the total information. The emphasis of this research is on controlling decentralized systems in the presence of uncertainty, which can be uncertainty in inter-subsystem communication latency or uncertainty in the dynamics or parameters of the subsystems themselves. The intellectual merits of this project are to advance foundational knowledge in the science of decentralized control and to produce computationally efficient control algorithms. This research has the potential to impact several different application areas and to serve as a guide to practice for engineers and system designers.

Optimal decentralized control is generally intractable, yet certain broad classes of problems can be efficiently solved. This project will leverage recent structural results for these tractable instances with the goal of elucidating universal architectures that allow for simple adaptations in the face of uncertainty in the subsystems or latency in their communication. To achieve this goal, the project will bring to bear tools and insights from the fields of optimal control, robust and nonlinear control, delayed systems, and decentralized control.

por.por_cntn:
This project concerned optimal decentralized control. Traditional control systems are used in essentially every engineering application. From commercial aircraft to smartphones to the modern power grid, control systems use feedback from sensors to make real-time decisions that ensure the safety, reliability, efficiency, and performance of complex systems. Traditionally, control systems are "centralized", meaning that a single computer acquires all sensor data and makes all decisions. However, emerging applications are increasingly "decentralized", meaning that there are multiple decision-makers with access to different subsets of the available information at different times. One example is the power grid, which is spatially distributed, and it would be too slow and risky to have all decisions be made from one central location. Another example is bilateral teleoperation, where a surgeon can perform a surgery on a patient in a different hospital by remotely controlling a robot. In this case, the presence of network latency is unavoidable and using centralized control would cause a severe performance degradation.

Centralized control is very well understood and ubiquitous in engineering systems. In many cases, it is possible to find the "optimal" controller that achieves the best possible trade-off between achievable performance and required effort. We also understand how to design performant centralized control strategies in the presence of delays or uncertainty. Decentralized control, on the other hand, is an emerging paradigm for which few established techniques exist. Finding an optimal decentralized controller is often an intractable problem, and delays or uncertainty further complicate the task. This project aimed to study specific cases of practical interest for which optimal decentralized control was possible. We had successful outcomes with respect to two prominent classes of decentralized control problems: (1) the various subsystems can interact over a network subject to delays and (2) the various subsystems have uncertainty in their dynamics, and we seek robustness in performance with respect to this uncertainty.

Our first outcome relates to so-called "dynamically decoupled systems". These are dynamical systems where the subsystems exert no direct influence on each other. However, the subsystems can communicate with one another (subject to latency) and make decisions based on the information communicated. This setting is appropriate, for example, for studying multi-agent systems such as a network of fire-fighting drones working together to cover a vast geographic area. It is also appropriate for teleoperation. We showed that for the dynamically decoupled case with delays, we can efficiently compute optimal control strategies. Moreover, these control strategies are tractable in the sense that they require only as much real-time computation to implement as their corresponding centralized counterparts. Finally, we show that optimal controllers for dynamically decoupled systems have an elegant modular structure, which allows for easy tuning and opens the door to future enhancements. See Fig. 1 for an illustration of the optimal controller architecture from the point of view of a single subsystem.

Our second outcome relates to robust control in the presence of uncertainty. It has been known for over 50 years that optimal centralized controllers (specifically, linear quadratic regulators) have innate robustness properties that make them a viable choice even when there is uncertainty in the system being controller. However, there is no corresponding result for decentralized control. We derived the first result of this kind by showing that under certain mild assumptions, decentralized linear quadratic regulators are also robust to model uncertainty.

Ultimately, this project advanced the state of the art in the emerging paradigm of decentralized control, both in terms of our fundamental understanding of what is possible, and in terms of what sorts of controllers we can compute and how to implement them.
